moves.1. e3: This is an unusual opening: doesn't claim any center, but does release the queen and light square bishop.
moves.2. d4 Bf5: Pressure on c2 pawn, develop bishop outside pawn chain
moves.3. Bd3 e6: support bishop (...Bxd3 4. Qxd3 activates white queen)
moves.4. Nf3 Bg6 5. c3 Nf6: I'd like, perhaps to get the knight to e4.
moves.6. Bxg6 hxg6: fxg6 works, too. My idea here is to use the fact that the rook is released and possibly castle queenside later.
moves.7. Qb3 b6: Nbd7 looks interesting to trap (but not capture) white queen e.g. 7...Nbd7 8 Qxb7 Nb6 it fails to 9 a4 ... 10 a5, though
moves.8. Qb5+ Qd7 9. Qb3 Nc6 10. Ng5 Na5 11. Q: I can win the pinned pawn on b4 (my dark square bishop is X-ray attacking his dark square bishop)
moves.15... Bxa3 16. Qb3 Rxa5: Win the pawn, protect the bishop
moves.17. Nf3 Ne4: Attack the pawn on c3. My idea is to try to trade queens on c3 or c4 after ...Qc6 (I’m a piece up). I need to pay attention to my king safety (no threats right now)
moves.18. Ne5: This stops my Qc6 plan; can we trade on b5?
moves.18... Qb5 19. Qxb5+ Rxb5: Ok, piece up endgame. c3 pawn is hanging. What to do about possible c4?
moves.23. a4 Rb2+: My original idea here was to snap up the f-pawn after king moves to back rank
moves.24... Rxf2#: Now I get the pawn -and- checkmate
